newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Alpha-Beta calls draw speculation.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Alpha-Beta calls draw speculation.

text.p: Implied volatilities for Alpha-Beta Technology Inc options soared and volume ballooned as speculators bet on the outcome of the firm's test of a key drug, traders said.

"It's become a very speculative issue," said Michael Young, a market-maker for the Alpha-Beta options at the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE). "It's been kind of running that way for a week, week and a half."
Alpha-Beta August 10.0 calls were the second heaviest traded contract on CBOE, with about 4,700 contracts changing hands by mid-afternoon.
Implied volatility for the calls shot up to around 150 percent, compared with the stock's 60-day actual volatility of slightly above 70 percent.
The stock was up 1-3/16 at 9-5/8.
Alpha-Beta Technology's director of finance Bill Romeo declined to comment on the stock market activity and said nothing had been released by the company today.

Romeo, however, said the firm recently completed the phase-three trials of its Betafectin PGG-glucan at 40 sites and was expected to present preliminary results to a panel of independent infectious disease experts Thursday and Friday.

Within two weeks, the company is expected to disclose preliminary results of the trials through a press release, he told Reuters. Once a full analysis of the trials is completed, results are to be presented at medical forum.
The drug developed by Massachusetts-based Alpha-Beta is expected to reduce the incidence of patients who develop a serious post-surgical infection after undergoing major gastrointestinal surgery.
Young at CBOE said a lot of the smaller retail orders coming in through the exchange's automated execution system were call selling, presumably buy-write activity.
On the other hand, the larger professional orders coming into the pit were call buying, he added.

"The professional side seems to be taking a bet that there's going to be a big move in the stock," he said. "We don't really know what to make of it because there's been things written about it that this is kind of a make-or-break drug for the company."
The August 7.5 puts also had relatively good volume of more than 2,100 contracts.
"People are trying to buy the puts as protection and maintain long positions," Young said.
Elsewhere, Bay Networks Inc calls were active after the firm's better than expected earnings report released late Tuesday. August 32.5 calls traded 5,100 lots.
Dell Computer options were also hot as the stock gained 4-1/2 to 164-1/2, while bullish momentum players returned to Intel Corp calls.
Rod Jamieson, vice president of option strategies at EVEREN Securities, said technology issues were once again at center stage as the sector remained very choppy.
"One day it's going one way, the next day it's going the other way," he said. "It's perfect for option trading."
-- Shin Kishima/Chicago Derivatives Desk ((312-408-8750))
